content: The Prophet (peace be upon him) said: "The best of you are those who learn the Quran and teach it."
Islam's core message is simple yet profound: there is no god but Allah, and Muhammad is His messenger.
The five pillars—Shahada, Salah, Zakat, Sawm, and Hajj—form the foundation of Muslim life and practice.
Muslims believe in angels; they're spiritual beings created from light who serve Allah faithfully.
The Quran states: "Indeed, with hardship comes ease" (94:6); this brings comfort during trials.
Ramadan's purpose goes beyond fasting: it teaches self-discipline, empathy, and gratitude.
Three sacred mosques exist in Islam: Al-Masjid al-Haram (Mecca), Al-Masjid an-Nabawi (Medina), and Al-Aqsa (Jerusalem).
The Prophet taught: "A person's true wealth is the good they do in this world."
Muslims ask: "How can we serve Allah better?" The answer lies in serving His creation with kindness.
Faith (iman) requires six beliefs: Allah, angels, books, prophets, Day of Judgment, and divine decree.
The greeting "As-salamu alaykum" means "peace be upon you"; it reflects Islam's peaceful nature.
Scholars emphasize: knowledge without action is futile—practice what you preach!
